title: 103_s1159
content:
The "Women in the Armed Forces Commemorative Coins Act" authorizes the minting of coins to honor women who served in the US military. The Secretary of the Treasury will oversee the production of these coins. The Secretary is authorized to mint and issue specific denominations of coins, including five dollar gold coins and one dollar silver coins with specified weights, diameters, and compositions. These coins will be legal tender. SEC. 4. SOURCES OF BULLION. The Secretary will obtain gold for minting coins under existing law and silver only from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Minerals Stock Piling Act. SEC. 5. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of coins authorized under this Act shall symbolize women's service in the Armed Forces of the United States and include specific inscriptions. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant organizations and committees. The design of coins authorized under this Act will symbolize women's service in the Armed Forces of the United States and include specific inscriptions, selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant organizations and committees. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS. The Act authorizes the minting of coins in uncirculated and proof qualities, with only one mint facility used for each denomination and quality combination. The Secretary can start issuing the coins on November 1, 1993, but minting must stop one year after issuance begins. The Women in Military Service for America Memorial Foundation will be consulted for promotion of the coins. The Secretary may enter into a contract with the Foundation for promoting, advertising, or marketing the authorized coins under the Act. SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS.

The Secretary will sell coins minted under this Act at a price including face value, surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will have discounts, and prepaid orders will be accepted at a reasonable discount. Surcharges of $40 for 5 dollar coins and $11 for one dollar coins will apply.

SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the government for minting coins under this Act. Payment for coins must be made in full, with security or guarantee satisfactory to the Secretary. The Secretary transfers surcharges from coin sales to the Women in Military Service for America Memorial Foundation to create the Women in the Armed Forces Memorial. Excess funds are transferred to the Secretary for deposit in a designated account. The Comptroller General conducts annual audits of financial records. The Comptroller General conducts an annual audit of financial records related to the expenditure of amounts paid under subsection (a) for the Women in Military Service for America Memorial Foundation. The procurement of goods and services for minting coins under this Act is exempt from procurement regulations, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 11. COINAGE PROFIT FUND.

Deposits: All amounts received from the sale of coins issued under this Act shall be deposited in the coinage profit fund.

Payments: The Secretary shall pay the amounts authorized under section 9 from the coinage profit fund.

Expenditures: The Secretary shall charge the coinage profit fund with all expenditures under this Act.

NUMISMATIC PUBLIC ENTERPRISE FUND: The coins issued under this Act are subject to the provisions of section 5134 of title 31, United States Code, relating to the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund.
